Table 1 An outlook of remarkable characteristics of electrocatalytic action in 2D metallenes. Property Explanation Quantum effects and size dependence Due to their tiny size, quantum effects increase metallene materials' unique properties. Size-dependent electrical and catalytic activity gives smaller metallene structures distinct features. To understand how metallenes' quantum nature contributes to their extraordinary electrocatalytic activity, study their size-dependent properties. Coupling of heteroatoms in catalysis Metallene materials often include heteroatoms. Heteroatoms can change the electric architecture and create catalytically active spots, affecting catalytic activity. Heteroatoms can boost catalytic activity with metal atoms by promoting reaction routes or providing more reactant binding sites. Stability and poison-resistance The electrocatalytic strength of metallene materials is crucial. Without reaction byproducts, catalytic activity lasts longer and is more efficient. Metallenes are stable and can tolerate harsh electrocatalysis conditions due to their two-dimensional structure. Electronic structure and bandgap engineering The electrical structure of metallene materials determines their electrocatalytic activity. Atoms' two-dimensional lattice configurations caused different electrical properties. By altering the energy gap between the valence and conduction bands, bandgap engineering can change catalytic materials' electron transfer capability. Electrical structure fine-tuning boosts catalytic efficiency. Large surface area and active sites The high electrocatalytic activity of 2D metallene materials is due to their enormous surface area. Metallenes' two-dimensional structure and large exposed surface area provide several catalytic reaction sites. Electrocatalysis requires active spots on metallene surfaces to absorb and interact reactant molecules and transmit charge. Kinetics and reaction mechanism Understanding the metallene surface's mechanical and kinetic behavior is crucial. Effective intimate contact with reactants in 2D structure affects the entire reaction process. Tuning charge migration and average generation on metallene's surface controls catalytic efficiency. In several electrochemical processes, this is critical for building catalysts. Graphical abstract Due to the unsaturated coordinated atoms, increased conduction, and plenty of operational positions, electrochemically prepared 2D metallenes exhibit an exceptional electrocatalytic activity with potential applications including CO2 reduction, fuel oxidation, O2 evolution, and O2 reduction reactions in the context of sustainable energy conversion. In this article, we looked at metallenes, a novel class of two-dimensional (2D) metals that are attracting interest in the energy and catalysis sectors. Catalysis is one area where their exceptional physicochemical and electrical characteristics might be useful. Metallenes are unique because they include several metal atoms that are not in a coordinated bond. This makes them more active and improves their atomic utilization, which in turn increases their catalytic potential. This article delves into the potential of two-dimensional metals as electrocatalysts for carbon dioxide reduction, fuel oxidation, oxygen evolution, and oxygen reduction reactions in the context of sustainable energy conversion. Owing to the exceptionally high surface-to-volume ratio, large surface area as well as their optimized atomic use efficiency, 2D materials defined by atomic layers are crucial for surface-related sustainable energy applications. Due to its exceptional properties, such as high conductivity and the ability to enhance the exposure of active metal sites, 2D metallenes have recently attracted a lot of interest for use in catalysis, electronics, and energy-related applications. With their highly mobility, adjustable surface states, and electrical structures that can be fine-tuned, 2D metallenes are promising nanostructure materials for use in energy conversion with the sustainable applications. Keywords Metallenes Electrocatalysts Electrochemical processes Atomically thin structure 1 Introduction The increasing need for energy has led to a rise in the consumption of fossil fuels, which is a concern given the scarcity of these resources and the severe risks they pose to the environment [1,2]. Hydroelectricity, wind power, and solar power have all received a lot of attention as potential, sustainable alternatives to fossil fuels in the last several decades [3]. There is a pressing need to create very efficient energy conversion and storage technologies due to the finite distribution of these ecologically valuable resources [3,4]. Hydrogen fuel with a low carbon content as well as high energy density has demonstrated to be an attractive option for storing the energy produced by these renewable sources [5,6]. Among the potential fuels of the future, hydrogen is highly regarded [7]. The most promising methods for hydrogen generation are electro and photo-catalytic water degradation because they are both cost-effective and environmentally friendly [8]. In the realm of energy renovation and storage, electrocatalysis is a cornerstone. It has great promise for the advancement of several technologies because of its essential role in facilitating electrically driven chemical processes. This complex area of electrochemistry has the potential to pave the way for greener, more efficient, and more efficient energy conversion processes. Using catalysts carefully to speed up electrochemical processes is the essence of electro-catalysis [9]. The exploitation of catalytic agent to electrochemical processes occurring at electrode surface is known as electrocatalysis. In their mediating role, these catalysts reduce the activation energy needed for individual processes, which in turn increases the efficiency and pace of those reactions. Electrocatalysts enhance the intended reactions while reducing the number of undesired side reactions by supplying alternate reaction routes. When it comes to electrocatalysis, fuel cells are among the most important uses. Electrochemical fuel cells can transform chemical energy into electrical energy without any intermediaries. Anode electrocatalysts enable fuel oxidation and cathode electrocatalysts reduce oxygen, respectively, allowing for efficient power generation. One of the most important applications of electrocatalysis is water electrolysis, which separates oxygen and hydrogen from water. Hydrogen generation becomes greener choices and practical for energy storage and fuel applications with the advantage of effective electrocatalysts, which assist in driving the electrolysis processes with decreased energy result. In addition, electro-catalysis is playing a bigger and bigger role in cleaning up polluted areas. Electrocatalysts contribute a major participation in the advancement of sustainable and efficient wastewater treatment methods by facilitating reactions that decompose pollutants and hazardous chemicals. Thanks to a lot of hard work in R&D, electrocatalysis has come a long way in the last few years. In their never-ending quest to improve catalytic activity and selectivity, scientists and engineers are delving deeper into new materials, design tactics, and reaction processes. These developments show a lot of potential for reducing environmental problems and radically altering renewable energy systems. Research into two-dimensional (2D) materials as co-catalysts to improve photo catalytic H2 generation has been on the rise since the 2004 discovery of monolayer graphene [10,11]. Compared to bulk nanomaterials or other types of nanomaterials, materials with an ultrathin 2D structure have extraordinary chemical, electrical, and catalytic capabilities [12–14] due to the special electron confinement that exists in two dimensions. Since the exfoliation of the first 2D nanocrystal, graphene, there has been a tremendous explosion in the family of 2D materials [15]. The extraordinary two-dimensional materials known as graphene analogues have an optimized atomic usage efficiency and an exceptionally high surface-to-volume ratio, making them crucial for surface-related applications. It exhibits an excellent catalytic as well as electrical [16–18] properties. It also exhibited the efficient optoelectronic properties [19–22]. These materials are referred as transition metal dichalcogenides (e.g., MoS2 [23], WS2 [24], g-C3N4 [25] for their exceptional high surface-to-volume ratio as well as their surface-related applications. The layered double hydroxides [26] that are referred as 2D materials in recent research as electrocatalyst. As a bonus, the 2D shape shortens the path that charge haulers take to accomplish the active site, which in turn increases photocatalytic efficiency by avoiding charge carrier recombination [27]. Due to the unique electron confinement in two dimensions, materials with an ultrathin two-dimensional (2D) structure display chemical, electronic, and catalytic properties that are unmatched by bulk materials or other types of nanomaterials [28–34]. The family of two-dimensional materials has seen tremendous growth since graphene, the first two-dimensional nanocrystal, was exfoliated. Because of their exceptionally high surface-to-volume ratio and, by extension, their optimized atomic use efficiency, graphene analogs defined by atomic layers-a unique class of two-dimensional materials are crucial for surface-related applications. Due to its exceptional properties, such as high conductivity and the ability to enhance the exposure of active metal sites, metallenes, a relatively new 2D material, have recently attracted a lot of interest for use in catalysis, electronics, and energy-related applications [35–37]. With their highly mobile carriers, adjustable surface states, and electrical structures that can be fine-tuned, metallenes are promising materials for use in energy conversion devices. When talking about 2D materials, metallenes essentially means a class of materials made of metals and alloys that are atomically thin. Fig. 1 (a) automatically displays a synopsis of metallene categorization according to stated compositions and metal elements. The electrocatalytic performance of metallenes, which are constituted of noble metals such as Pd, Ir, and Rh, performed exceptionally well in real-world applications. Furthermore, several methods were devised to further enhance their performance, including atomic doping, surface modification, lattice engineering, etc. [38]. In addition, the enhanced performance of metallenes in the electrocatalysis of oxygen reduction was demonstrated by the recent success of PdMo bimetallene with four atomic layers, which prompted further research into metallenes as electrocatalysts for energy-related applications [39–41]. Metallene is defined using the same criteria as graphene. Metallenes are characterized in theory as single atomic layers made up of metal atoms. In the same way that graphene's high surface free energy allows it to take on atomically flat surfaces when deposited on a substrate, the monolayer structure's flexibility allows it to take on atomically curved surfaces when freestanding. When metal is reduced to a monolayer, its electrical characteristics are like those of graphene and metallenes, which is why the term “ene” is used to describe metal [42,43]. The graphene analogs that have been described so far may be broadly grouped into three types: (1) metal-free analogs such as carbon nitride, boron nitride, phosphorene, etc.; (2) transition metal compounds such as carbides (also known as MXenes), chalcogenide, hydroxide, etc.; (3) metallic materials such as monometallenes, bimetallenes, and trimetallenes, etc. Featured with laminar structures stacked by van der Waals forces, the first two categories can be synthesized via top-down exfoliation or bottom-up growth down to single atomic layers [41]. (Fig. 1b). 2D metallenes merge the advantages of 2D structures with the inherent qualities of metals; they have a plethora of active sites and exhibit significant structural flexibility. This means they often outperform their one, zero, and three-dimensional counterparts in electrocatalysis [26,44]. Metallenes have several advantages: (i) Nanosheets with uniform structures enhance inherent catalytic action and atomic usage productivity due to their horde of angles, phases, boundaries, and defects; (ii) Charge and mass transfer are facilitated by huge solid-liquid or solid-gas contact surface areas and small transference intervals; (iii) Almost every surface of the catalysts have the ability to intermingle by the electrolytic species or reagent in addition to join in reactions, and (iv) their structure is sharp with distinct dimensions, making them perfect precursors for additional alteration and understanding the catalytic mechanistic route [37,45]. Research into 2D metallenes as cost-effective and efficient electrocatalysts is attracting a lot of attention because of their remarkable properties. Because of these new advancements, we decided to make a summary of everything that goes into making 2D metallenes and how they help in electrocatalysis, especially in energy conversion. In this study, we focus on some of the major advancements in metallene manufacturing, characterization, and electrocatalytic applications. Here we provided a brief overview of the current state of the art regarding metallenes, including their synthesis, characterization, and electrocatalytic uses. A quick review of the fundamentals of metallene synthesis and characterization follows. Hydrogen evolution, oxygen reduction, alcohol and acid oxidation, CO2 reduction, and N2 reduction are some of the energy-related processes that we demonstrate after discussing the electrocatalytic characteristics of metallenes. Lastly, we review the current state of the art and discuss possible future directions regarding the difficulties and possibilities of synthesizing, characterizing, modelling, and maintaining the stability of metallenes for practical energy applications. 2 Attributes of two-dimensional metallenes Metallenes have unique characteristics that make them ideal for heterogeneous catalysis, distinguishing them from both bulk materials and other non-2D materials. One advantage of metallenes is their extremely high surface-to-volume ratios, which are a result of their extremely thin atomic structures. This allows for the exposure of extremely high proportions of coordinatively unsaturated metal atoms at the surface and edges of the material, which are typically thought of as active centers and could potentially enhance its catalytic performance [46]. As with “graphene,” “metallene” denotes a metal sheet with a single layer of thickness. Strictly speaking, it would denote a single-layer metal sheet. But getting your hands on them is next to impossible because of the difficulties in synthesizing freestanding monolayer metal sheets owing to thermo-dynamic instability [45]. Thus, metallenes are the popular name for 2D metals that are atomically thin and have a thickness of less than 5 nm. Typically, one may alter the unique characteristics of metallenes by adjusting their compositions, sizes, thicknesses, and surface chemistry. However, these characteristics are most affected by the metals' inherent properties. This highlights the need to organize metallenes into three primary categories. Metallenes are a class of compounds that includes gallenene (Ga-ene), germanene (Ge-ene), stanene (Sn-ene), plumbene (Pb-ene), antimonene (Sb-ene), etc. These substances are made up of elements that are part of the primary group. Metallenes derived from transition metals: This category includes metallenes that are derived from transition metals. Metals like gold, palladium, platinum, ruthenium, iridium, rhodium, and silver are all part of the noble metallenes subset; metals such as Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn are all part of the non-noble metallenes subset. The third category consists of metallenes that are derived from alloys, which are mixtures of several metals. Fig. 2 shows the summary and historical overview of various metallenes in the periodic table of elements. When compared to bulk equivalents and other non-2D materials, metallenes' exceptional properties make them ideal for heterogeneous catalysis. Because they are so thin at the atomic level, metallenes have an extremely high surface-to-volume ratio. This means that they can expose many coordinately unsaturated metal atoms on their surfaces and edges, which are commonly considered active sites [46]. Their catalytic performance may be improved by this exposure. As a result of flaws and dislocations, edge atoms are more likely to be coordinatively unsaturated, which might increase their catalytic activity. With metallenes, functionalization is a breeze, whether it's ligand modification, alloying, doping, or defect engineering, thanks to the fully exposed active sites. They can be easily modified in terms of electronic structure, stability, physicochemical properties, and overall catalytic activity because of this flexibility. At the same time, the elevated superficial strength of the metal atoms and the descent constant surface areas of the metallene surfaces considerably improve the adsorption of reactants onto these surfaces. Metallenes exhibit excellent promise for catalytic use owing to their interplay of characteristics [47]. Furthermore, reactant and product diffusion lengths, as well as charge transfer distances, are significantly reduced due to the ultra-thin structure of metallenes. Mass and charge transport are both accelerated by this effect in catalytic reactions. In addition, many metallenes have a wide spectrum of absorption, going all the way from UV to near-infrared. This property enables its use in photodynamic therapy, photocatalysis, photothermal hyperthermia, and photocatalysis. It should be mentioned that many metallenes do not have a bandgap, which means they cannot be used as photocatalysts directly. On the other hand, there exist semiconductors with bandgaps that change with thickness, such as Bi-ene and Sb-ene [48]. Metallenes of noble metals like gold and silver have a strong localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) effect, and when combined with semiconductor photocatalysts, they greatly improve the transfer and separation of photogenerated carriers. As a result, their photocatalytic effectiveness is greatly enhanced [49]. The problem is that metallenes have a very high surface energy. Especially when exposed to air, these materials' surface atoms are highly reactive in contrast to bulk metals', turning them into oxidizable and degradable. To keep their special qualities, it is necessary to keep them in their metallic state. 3 Metallenes properties as electrocatalysts Chemical synthesis and pollution management are only two examples of the many applications of traditional three-dimensional metal catalysts. Yet, there are a few drawbacks to these materials that have prompted scientists to investigate other catalytic materials. Problems with activity and selectivity in particular reactions, surface area limitations resulting in slower reaction rates, expensive production processes owing to scarce metals, uncertainty and leaching of dynamic metallic species, intoxication or inhibiting potential, and operating complications by the employment of intense environments are among these challenges. Concerns about the environment also stem from the fact that certain metal catalysts are poisonous and non-renewable. Researchers are looking at new catalytic materials with different characteristics and possible benefits over the old 3D metal catalysts to solve these problems [36,50]. These materials include mono atomic catalysts, two-dimensional metallic species, nanoparticles, and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). We can create more effective and long-lasting catalytic technologies for a variety of uses if we can overcome these obstacles. 2D metal metallenes stand out among the rest of these materials as having promised future uses. To acquire improved catalytic characteristics and minimize excessive overpotentials, the fundamental issue in electrocatalysis is to optimize the bonding strengths of chemical intermediates, adherent to Sabatier's concept. Because of their almost nonexistent overpotential catalytic activity, noble metals such as Pt, Ru, and Ir have served as crucial benchmarks [51–53]. Nevertheless, because of their high cost, research into less costly alternatives derived from transition metals has been initiated. While transition metals are a viable replacement, the increased activity that comes with them typically comes at the cost of larger overpotentials [53]. Improving the intrinsic activity of active sites is an important part of catalyst design since it allows for larger loading of transition metals or lower utilization of noble metals without sacrificing performance. At the same time, researchers are looking at two-dimensional nanostructures that have very active catalytic components. A major emphasis in current research is the development of nanostructures with the purpose of efficiently interacting with certain chemical reactants. Researchers are also concentrating on creating two-dimensional nanostructures with efficient catalytic entities and a high correspondence for certain chemical reagents [54]. This field of study has emerged as an important avenue for future research. A subset of low-dimensional nanostructures, including atomically thin 2D materials, is attracting increasing attention. This subset includes 0D, 1D, and 2D materials. Among these materials' distinctive qualities are their accessible active spots, high specific surface area, and attractive shape [55]. They also have unsaturated surface coordination, great efficiency in maximizing atomic usefulness, and good conductivity. The mass transfer of reactants towards the substantially active sources is greatly affected by the enhanced functionality that results from the combination of these extraordinary physicochemical features. Therefore, these materials are excellent candidates for a wide range of uses due to their remarkable catalytic activity. Researchers have recently delved deep into the nanoscale morphology of metals, studying their size and structure to uncover possible uses in areas such as biomedicine, photonics, sensors, and catalysis. It is well-established in the field of catalysis that the activity, selectivity, and stability of metallic nanoparticles may be dramatically affected by modifying their size and shape [43]. Improvements in reactant interaction, increased reactive surface sites, amplified volume to superficial area proportions, and the contact of certain crystal flat surface all contribute to the increased catalytic activity. Several people are interested in atomically thin 2D materials as possible catalysts, just as graphene. These substances are known as metallenes. The thickness of these materials is below 4 nanometers, and they are composed entirely of metallic atoms [56,57]. Due to their intriguing properties, metallenes are appealing for use in catalytic processes. Their electron transport characteristics, for instance, are superior to or on par with those of other two-dimensional materials like TMDs [58,59]. A maximum specific loading of catalytically active sites is possible because the atomically thin layers are abundant at the surface and edges with under-coordinated metal atoms [41]. These unique properties make metallenes a promising candidate for application in catalytic technology development (Table 1 ). 4 Synthesis of two-dimensional metallenes The controlled manufacture of metallene allows for the modification of their electrochemical characteristics and catalytic efficacy by adjusting their thickness, content, and crystal structure. Several methods for synthesizing 2D metal nanomaterials with regulated thickness, content, and crystal structure have been established, thanks to the work of numerous groups [26,60]. There are three main methodologies for synthesizing metallene, as shown in Table 2 . These are the bottom-up wet-chemical procedures, the top-down exfoliation methods, and the topotactic metallization approaches (Fig. 3 ). Metallene nanosheets may be made using either the top-down, bottom-up or topotactic metallization approaches, as is common with other 2D materials [61,62]. Mechanical cleavage, electrochemical exfoliation, ultrasonic exfoliation, and plasma-assisted techniques are all examples of top-down processes that use mechanical forces and intercalation to create nanosheets from bulk or powdered materials. On the other hand, chemical methods such as molecular beam epitaxy, chemical vapor deposition (CVD), and wet chemical synthesis are utilized in the bottom-up approach. To construct the nanosheets chemically, atoms or molecules are either included or combined in a planar fashion. But since they tend to connect with metals in all directions, many metallenes prefer to form 3D crystals that are structurally quite symmetrical. Because of this, their nanostructures with a lot of unsaturated surface atoms are not stable. So, using the top-down approach to directly separate bulk intermetallic layers is not easy. Surfactants, ligands, or templates can be introduced to create atomically thin metallenes. These thin structures are formed when these additions lower the surface bond energy or modify the anisotropic growth kinetics. Another option for making metallenes is the bottom-up chemical synthesis approach. Methods like initiator-assisted breakdown of precursors or meticulous temperature control are part of this approach. Metal nuclei are produced by reduction processes that are triggered by these decomposing precursors. By interacting with surfactants, ligands, or templates, the nuclei can facilitate lateral development while preventing the addition of metal atoms in the longitudinal plane. It is possible to gradually expand the edges of metallenes by carefully controlling the reaction kinetics. 4.1 Exfoliation One way to physically manipulate a material having layered qualities is to subject it to mechanical cleavage, sometimes called mechanical exfoliation. This technique separates the material into thinner layers. Graphene, several multilayer semiconductors, and some metal chalcogenides are materials that benefit greatly from this method. The bulk material is usually placed on a substrate or held in place using adhesive tape during mechanical cleavage. When a result of the mechanical forces used, the layers of the material peel apart when the tape is swiftly peeled away. Eventually, nanosheets are formed by this peeling process, and they can get thinner and thinner until they approach monolayer thickness. The mechanical cleavage method has the distinct benefit of being easy to understand and use. Simply changing the exfoliation cycle frequency, the nanosheet thickness may be directly controlled. On top of that, for specific uses, this process yields nanosheets that are defect-free. The mechanical cleavage approach is useful, but it can't handle large amounts of data or be repeated accurately. Its labor-intensive nature means it depends mostly on human manipulation and may not be suited for mass manufacturing. Metallenes derived from magnesium and aluminum have recently been the subject of fruitful research and development. A new method for ultrasonically exfoliating Mg nanoparticles into two-dimensional nanocrystals at reduced temperatures was developed by Zhang and colleagues [63]. As part of this procedure, they treated the magnesium with liquid nitrogen to alter its slip system. Using ultrasound, Lu and colleagues were able to exfoliate tiny pieces of aluminum foil into 2D sheets, with diameters of around 1 mm in ethylene glycol [64]. Additionally, Yadav et al. [65] produced 2D metal alloys from 3D quasicrystal precursors by employing a scalable technique. The 2D structures were extracted from the decagonal quasicrystals of bulk Al66Co17Cu17 alloy by robust exfoliation in a pressurized ultrasonic reactor. Significant outcomes of ultrasonic exfoliation, mostly influenced by ultrasonic power and time, are the dimensions and solidness of the resultant two-dimensional metallene. Ultrasonic exfoliation may be mass-produced at a reasonable cost, but that won't solve all the problems. There is still a lack of production capacity for very thin 2D nanomaterials, especially monolayers. The solvents used are typically harmful organic reagents, and the nanosheets that come out are not always consistent. These concerns have proven to be rather challenging and have not been adequately addressed. The process of exfoliating layered platinum oxide allowed for the creation of Pt nanosheets [66]. The first successful synthesis of monolayer Pt nanosheets was also achieved by refining the technique and changing the reduction conditions. In the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), these Pt nanosheets with a single layer showed remarkable activity. For the careful electrochemical reduction of CO2 to acetaldehyde, a new catalyst type has been developed, which uses ferromagnetic hexagonal-close-packed (hcp) cobalt nanosheets (NSs) [67]. The nanosheets continuously produce ethanal as the main product in a 0.5 M KHCO3 solution over a limit of reduction potentials from −0.3 to −1.0 V (vs. SHE), with minor quantities of ethanol and methanol also generated. The faradic efficiency (FE) for ethanal reaches 60% at a reduction potential of 0.4 V, with current densities of 5.1 mA cm−2 and an MA of 3.4 A g−1. Ethanal, ethanol, and methanol together have an overall FE of 82%. Fig. 4 (a) shows the suggested method for creating ultrathin 2D bismuth (Bi) nanosheets via liquid exfoliation, which aims to improve the efficiency of electrocatalytic CO2 conversion [68]. The thin Bi nanosheets, with a range of sizes that extend below the micron level, are displayed in the TEM images in Fig. 4(b). The X-ray diffraction pattern is shown in Fig. 4(c), allowing for the measurement of a lattice gap of 0.40 nm. This number lines up with the preferred orientation of the Bi (003) plane. Furthermore, as demonstrated in Fig. 4(d), SEM image of Bi nanosheets prepared by electrochemical reduction was employed to ascertain that the multilayer bismuth nanosheets' thickness varied between 1.99 nm and a handful of nanometers. Improving CO2 adsorption and reaction kinetics, the increased abundance of boundary active points on these extremely fine Bi 2D films in contrast to bulk Bi greatly aided the conversion of CO2 to formate (HCOOH/HCOO−). By analyzing the lower Gibbs free energy, it was found using Density Functional Theory (DFT) estimates that the phase concerning the synthesis of *OCOH mostly happened on boundary points alternative to facet sites. The Bi nanosheets outperformed bulk Bi in terms of formate generation, boasting an incredible FE of 90% and an amazing electron flow density of 17 mA cm−2 at a potential of 1.1 V (vs. RHE), because of their descent conduction and abundance of peripheral positions. In addition, the Bi nanosheets maintained their catalytic activity even after being subjected to test them for 10 h straight Fig. 4(e–h) [69]. 4.2 Surfactant-assisted preparation method A synthetic method known as surfactant-directed synthesis involves the use of surfactant molecules to influence the development of materials with desired structures or features [70]. Because of their amphiphilic nature, surfactants include both hydrophilic and hydrophobic groups of hydrogen atoms. Here, surfactants are carefully added to the reaction mixture. Because of their distinct characteristics, surfactants may react with many substances in the reaction blend, including molecules of solvents or precursors. The surfactant's hydrophobic portion seeks water and organizes itself into micelles or other structures, while the hydrophilic portion is drawn to the liquid phase. Nanoscale material nucleation, growth, and organization may be controlled by means of these surfactant assemblies, which form contained environments or templates. Nanomaterials may have their size, shape, and morphology fine-tuned by manipulating reaction conditions, such as the kind and concentration of surfactants. By directing the structure and organization of the developing material towards the self-assembly of surfactants, surfactant-directed synthesis provides a flexible and efficient method for designing and fabricating nanomaterials with suitable qualities. Nano rods, quantum wires, buckytubes, and additional nanostructures with regulated properties for different purposes have been produced by this process, which has seen extensive usage in areas including materials science, catalysis, and nanotechnology. Reducing hydrogen tetrachloroaurate resulted in the creation of very pure monodisperse gold nanoplates with controlled sizes, with less sodium citrate being used as the reductant [45]. There was kinetic regulation of the reaction pathway in the presence of poly (vinyl pyrrolidone) (PVP). The final nanoplates' dimensions and geometric form were, however, greatly affected by the sodium citrate and PVP to hydrogen tetrachloroaurate molar ratios. The outstanding single-crystalline characteristics and excellent surface plasmon absorption throughout the near-infrared region (690–1980 nm) were revealed by these nanosheets, which had size limits of 75 to 490 nm in breadth and 8 to 42 nm in thickness. The synthetic nano blocks made of these gold nanoplates allowed for the precise and versatile fabrication of single-crystalline nanocomponents such as nano scaled gears and complex nano scaled letters. An easy way to make ultrathin 2D palladium nanosheets (PdNSs) is by using a bottom-up synthetic approach that intentionally exposes surface facets [71]. As seen in Fig. 5 , their synthetic strategy relies on forming PdNSs in an aqueous solution using the nanoconfined lamellar mesophases of amphiphilic functional surfactants as a template. The epitaxial growth of the (100)-, (110)-, and (111)-bare facial area of very fine PdNSs is achieved by means of the extensive fiber surface-active substances' selective adsorption of functionalities along with halide counterions on the selected Pd flat surface. They were able to accurately regulate the surface area of extremely fine 2D PdNSs using such broad and accessible preparation technique, which opens an opportunity to examine facet-supported catalytic execution. Within the framework of electrocatalysis for H2 production processes (HERs), they prove that PdNSs exposed to (101) have better stability and catalytic activity than versions subjected to (110) and (111), in addition to bulk Pd. The conclusions shed light on the logical layout of surfactant models for different types of two-dimensional metal nanosheets, which is a significant step forward. An additional research paper details an easy way to create 2D PdAg alloy nano dendrites, which are effective electrocatalysts for the electrooxidation of ethanol [72,73]. The structure-directing agent octadecyl trimethylammonium chloride is used in this procedure, which entails co-reducing Pd and Ag precursors in an aqueous solution. The end products have a high number of uncoordinated sites and a tiny thickness (6–8 nm) due to their arbitrary planner branched framework and elevated surface sites. They show remarkable operational stability in cycling and chronoamperometric experiments performed during ethanol electrooxidation, and they have increased electrocatalytic activity as shown by a large specific current. The results of the control tests show that the electrical and structural effects work together to provide these improvements. There is no metal other than Pd that can catalyze the electrochemical reduction of CO2 to formate with almost little overpotential. Regrettably, even minute quantities of CO, a byproduct, can cause serious poisoning. Its selectivity and stability also decrease with increasing overpotential. To achieve sustained and selective formate synthesis, this work presents a solution where Pd is alloyed with Cu in the arrangement of 2D nano dendrites [74]. A unique and programmed series of experimental settings that promote fast in-plane development while limiting out-of-plane growth is precisely controlled to produce these bimetallic nanostructures. The alloy's final product shows exceptional catalytic activity in reducing carbon dioxide to format, with amazing selectivity and stability down to a cathodic working potential of only 0.4 V, because of a combination of electrical and nano structuring effects. A function for Cu atoms in weakening *CO adsorption and stabilizing *OCHO adsorption on neighboring Pd atoms was revealed by computational simulations, which corroborate these observations. 4.3 Vapor accretion approaches Producing two-dimensional metallenes using vapour deposition technique is a promising new area of research. The process requires a controlled vacuum environment to deposit metal atoms or molecules onto a surface. By adjusting factors like temperature, pressure, and depositing speed, scientists may manipulate the growth and final appearance of the metal layers. Vapour deposition allows us to controllably create extremely thin layers of metal for these 2D metallenes. Vapour deposition may be accomplished in a variety of ways, with CVD and molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) being two examples. Crystals that are both pure and well-structured may be created with MBE by simply depositing metal atoms onto a surface. CVD, in contrast, may cover more ground since it uses surface reactions of gases containing metals. The ability to produce large quantities of 2D metallene material with the desired characteristics is one of the many neat things about vapor deposition. We may get the same outcome every time since it is likewise replicable. Since this technology may assist in the creation of well-performing custom-made 2D metal structures, it has already found applications in electronics, catalyst production, and optoelectronics. By carefully adjusting the experimental settings, ultrathin 2D nanosheets may be achieved on the substrate. Germanium nanosheets were grown on Si (100) wafers using UHV-CVD (ultra-high-vacuum chemical vapor deposition) technique, and a highly crystallinity thin-layered germanene was formed by an annealing process [75]. PVD refers to the vacuum-assisted physical deposition of ions onto a collective surface. As previously reported by Kuriakose and colleagues [76], millimeter-gauge single-stage antimonene nanolayers were deposited on controlled SiO2 medium reactants using a physical vapor deposition technique. The formation of broader nanolayers or mono-phase antimonene crystals may be customized according to needs by adjusting temperature gradients in the deposition tube. Compared to other approaches, vapor deposition technology has many benefits when it comes to synthesizing two-dimensional materials. Changes to gas pressure, gas kinetic diffusion, temperature range, and conducting period are among the process factors that can control the deposition rate. Be warned, though; vapor deposition frequently calls for inert gas conditions and high temperatures, which drives up manufacturing costs. A way to produce antimonene on a PdTe2 substrate was devised by Wu and colleagues [77]. A state-of-the-art apparatus known as MBE was employed in a very high vacuum chamber. Using extraordinarily high pressures, they initially separated the PdTe2 substrate into individual crystals. After that, they let the antimony evaporate on the newly sliced PdTe2. By repeating the MBE method, Niu and colleagues were able to directly produce high-quality two-dimensional antimonene on a tailored copper oxide superfacial [78]. Beginning with a Cu (III) limpid, they deposited a thin coating of copper oxide. After that, Sb was cold applied to the layer from an ultra-pure boron nitride crucible. Lastly, the thin antimonene layer was obtained by means of a thermal treatment under high pressure. The team lead by Waller demonstrated, via a procedure known as solid-source MBE [79,80], how to produce antimonene on a germanium surface. Their high-quality, condition-stable antimonene was discovered by integrating theory with super-zoomed-in imaging. After growing a fine bismuth film on Si(111) using MBE, Walker and colleagues transferred it to a second silicon chip covered with epoxy resin using a complex technique known as double cantilever fracture technology [81]. The structural, optical, and electrical properties of the original film were faithfully preserved by the transferred film. This method of MBE requires specialized vacuum and pressure settings, which can be rather costly. However, it has its uses, and one of them is the production of high-quality 2D thin films on a wide scale. 4.4 Topotactic metallization strategies Beyond the diverse methods mentioned above, topotactic metallization of the layered metal-containing compounds represents another facile and effective strategy to realize the controllable synthesis of metallenes [82–87]. Specifically, the non-metallic groups (e.g., OH−, O2 −) in the interlayers and/or in-planes of the layered metal compounds are extracted under reductive conditions while their layered structures are maintained, leading to the formation of metallenes. For instance, as shown in Fig. 6 (a–e), the ultrathin Ni NS arrays with a thickness of 2.2 nm can be synthesized through the in situ topotactic reduction of Ni(OH)2 NSs under solvothermal conditions, in which the Ni NSs showed a single-crystalline lamellar structure with an exposed (111) facet [83]. Taking the same protocol, the ultrathin Ni-Mo alloy NSs with the thickness in the range of 2.0–2.1 nm was obtained from the NiMoO4 NS arrays precursor [84]. Moreover, it is worth noting that the mono-layered Ru NSs can be fabricated through the topotactic metallization of layered ruthenate under H2 atmosphere [85]. Similarly, the two-layer Ru NSs were also prepared via the H2 reduction of RuO2 NSs [86]. Besides, Mo-incorporated Ni NSs [87] and Co NSs [88,89] have also been successfully fabricated from their hydroxide precursors under reductive atmosphere. Alternatively, compared with normal chemical topotactic metallization methods, the in situ electrochemical reduction process seems to be a more promising strategy to achieve the conversion of layered metal-containing compounds to their corresponding metallenes, since electrons are the most effective and green reductants [90–92]. For example, monolayer Pt can be synthesized through the electrochemical reduction of layered PtO, while only nanoparticle-assembled porous nanosheets with larger thickness were obtained via the chemical reduction method [93]. Moreover, combining the selective etching and electroreduction process, Liu et al. synthesized the porous Pd NSs from porous Pd-Ni oxide nanoplates [68]. Not only that, atomically thin Ni NSs and Zn NSs can also be fabricated through the electrochemical reduction of 2D Ni-S coordination polymer [94] and ultrathin ZnS layer [95] respectively. In another work, Zhang et al. reported the fabrication of nano defective Cu NSs via the in situ electroreduction of CuO NSs under CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) process (Fig. 6f). It is worth noting that the generated nanopores in Cu NSs can create concentrated atomic defects (Fig. 6g), which is beneficial to improve the electrochemical performance [85]. Impressively, taking the similar strategies, the fabrication of various Bi-ene catalysts has been widely reported in recent years [96,97]. For example, Han et al. presented the in situ topotactic transformation of bismuth oxyhalide NSs to ultrathin Bi NSs via chronoamperometry reduction in NaHCO3 [90], while Sargent and coworkers employed the repeated cyclic voltammetry cycles in KHCO3 to achieve the same goal [97]. Analogously, Bi-enes were also prepared through the electrochemical reduction of various layered inorganic Bi-based compound precursors, including BiOI, BiOCOOH, Bi2O2CO3, Bi2O3, and BiVO4 [46,98]. Moreover, compared with conventional inorganic materials, MOFs feature more tunable chemical structures and morphologies, making them more feasible to obtain advanced Bi-enes via the in situ electrochemical conversion of 2D structured Bi-MOFs [97]. As shown in Fig. 6(h and i), we first achieved the in situ electrochemical transformation of Bi-based metal-organic layers (Bi-MOLs) to atomically thin Bi-ene with an average thickness of only 1.28–1.45 nm in a recent study [46]. Furthermore, our recent work and some other researchers have also discovered that Bi-enes can be obtained from the in situ electrochemical conversion of some non-layer-structured Bi-based compounds [98–102]. We speculate that the evolution process could undergo the formation of some Bi-based compounds (e.g., Bi2O2CO3) with layer structures, and the subsequent topotactic metallization process [103]. Different synthetic approaches for Metallenes have been discussed and shortly presented in the Table 3 . 5 Potential uses of metallenes in heterogeneous catalytic processes Metallenes are highly esteemed heterogeneous catalysts due to their exceptional physicochemical features, such as their large specific surface area, ultrahigh exposure of unsaturated metal sites, and faulty sites. For helping readers to comprehend how metallenes excel above traditional metal-based catalysts, we present their uses in a range of heterogeneous catalysis applications, such as electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, and heterogeneous organic catalysis. This section will focus on the uses of metallenes in electrocatalysis since they hold great promise for energy conversion and storage. The exceptional physicochemical features of metallenes, such as their huge definite surface area, extensive interaction with unsaturated metal centers, and the existence of faulty sites, have made them highly sought-after heterogeneous catalysts. We want to illuminate the many uses of metallenes in heterogeneous catalysis domains, such as electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, and heterogeneous organic catalysis, within this framework. To demonstrate the clear benefits of metallenes over conventional catalysts based on metal, this investigation is vital. We explore the pivotal function of metallenes in electrocatalysis in this section, particularly considering the exciting possibilities they provide for energy conversion and storage [38,40,46,61,70,81,96,104–114]. 5.1 Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) Noble metals like Pt, Pd, Ir, and Rh typically catalyze the HER, an essential half-reaction for producing hydrogen via water splitting. The HER has made excellent use of a range of noble metallenes by capitalizing on their 2D morphology. As an example, Cheng and colleagues showed that imperfect and porous Ir metallenes performed better in HER tests, with measurements such as a double-layer capacitance of 4.30 mF cm2, a Tafel slope of 31.2 mV dec−1, and an overpotential of 14 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 [40]. Thanks to its ultrathin 2D shape, excellent conductivity, and huge specific surface area, Ir metallene outperformed Pt/C in terms of HER activity. Furthermore, the HER performed better in acidic conditions because of the partly hydroxylated surface that was obtained using polyallylamine (PAH) modification, which exhibited a modified electronic structure and efficient proton carriers. Metallenes can change their HER performance depending on the surface aspect that is exposed. Liu and colleagues compared the HER activity of Pd metallenes with (100), (111), and (110) facets to further understand the facet dependent HER activity [72]. Compared to Pd metallenes exposed to (111) and (110) planes, those with (100) surface faces exhibited the lowest overpotentials at 10, 50, and 100 mA cm−2 in an acidic electrolyte. This is because the (100) planes of Pd metallene have the ideal balance between hydrogen adsorption and desorption (Fig. 7 a and a1). In addition, the anisotropic 2D shape significantly slows down the electrochemical ripening and dissolution of Pd metallene, leading to great HER durability and just a little amount of degradation after 20 h (Fig. 7a2 and a3). Inducing a strain and ligand effect by including either metallic or nonmetallic components can further increase the HER activity of metallenes. For instance, it has been shown that bimetallenes, such RuRh and IrRh metallenes, are excellent electrocatalysts towards the HER [112,113]. The electronic structure of metallenes can be modified by intercalation of light atoms, which are characterized as being inside the third-row elements, in addition to by the formation of alloys [70,114]. Because of their significantly lower atomic radii, light atoms can penetrate the interstitial sites of the lattice, causing the lattice to grow and facilitating charge transfer between the host and guest atoms, in contrast to the secondary metal atoms found at the lattice point of metallenes. Light atoms boost metallene catalytic activity and selectivity through strain and ligand impact. Another way to increase the HER activity is to make Pd metallene amorphous. Pd-S metallene outperformed its crystalline counterparts in HER tests, according to our group's findings, since sulphuration caused Pd amorphization. (Fig. 7b–b3) [96]. This enhancement is a result of the amorphous structure and the ligand effect, both of which modify the electronic structure. The HER activity was enhanced due to the weaker hydrogen bonding caused by the longer Pd–Pd bond length and higher d-band downshift in the amorphous structure. Surface Pd atoms' coordination environments were changed by the presence of S atoms and the disordered surface, which may have resulted in an abundance of active sites on Pd-S metallene for the HER. 5.2 Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is often thought of as a limiting factor in proton exchange membrane (PEM) electrolyzes. This is because, in contrast to the hydrogen evolution process (HER), its reaction rates are slower and its surplus energy needs are larger. Even though there has been a lot of study on transition metal electrocatalysts as a replacement for noble metal electrocatalysts, the most cutting-edge OER electrocatalysts even now use valuable metals such as Ir [46] and Ru [40]. Scientists have newly brought attention to the positive results that have been seen when using 2D designs of Ir and Ru electrocatalysts, as well as their alloys, as catalysts for the OER. The 2D arrangement of structured Ir nanosheets shown by Zhao and colleagues [72] serves as an example. The unique structural properties of these nanosheets, including highly electrophilic oxygen species, mixed-valence states, and well-organized mesostructured, allowed them to demonstrate exceptional OER capabilities. In an acidic environment, the optimized Ir IrO x /C catalysts demonstrated remarkable oxygen evolution reaction efficiency, with an overpotential of just 200 mV at 10 mA cm−2. This outperformed both commercially available IrO2 materials and more traditional Ir/C catalysts. Amorphous Ir nanosheets with a high content of unsaturated atoms were also created by the researchers. In acidic circumstances, these amorphous nanosheets showed excellent OER execution, requiring just a 260 mV overpotential at 10 mA cm−2. At 373 mV at 10 mA cm−2, this accomplishment stood out when contrasted with crystalline Ir nanolayers (277 mV at 10 mA cm−2) and industrial IrO2 catalysts [115]. The investigators examined the configurational modification of the amorphous Ir catalyst throughout the OER using imaging techniques such in situ X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (XAFS) and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM). The valence state of Ir stayed below + 4 throughout the OER process, according to their findings. The retention of a lower valence state in combination with the amorphous form of the Ir catalyst allowed for its high catalytic activity and excellent stability. The development of effective ruthenium-based electrocatalysts for the OER has taken precedence over Ir as the primary focus of research. The fact that Ru is less expensive than other metals in the platinum group is the main factor driving this. A major obstacle that develops during OER is the production of soluble RuO4, which significantly reduces stability and performance. An approach to this issue is to enhance the durability of Ru-based electrocatalysts by including other metals in the alloy. This is achieved by strengthening the Ru–O bonds, which inhibit the creation of soluble RuO4 species during the OER. The fabrication of Mn-doped ultrathin Ru nanosheet branches with naturally numerous edges is an example of a material that has been successfully used to create materials with remarkable electroactivity and durability in OER situations [116]. The electrical structure of Ru sites may be altered by doping the Ru crystal lattice with manganese (Mn) atoms, according to both experimental studies and computational conclusions utilizing density-functional theory (DFT). The Ru–O bonds are shrunk because of this change. The result was an alloyed catalyst with exceptional OER performance, displaying a high degree of stability and an extremely low overpotential of 196 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in an acidic setting. Nanosheets of IrRh alloy [117], RuIr solid solution alloys resembling nano coral [118], and channel rich RuCu nanosheets [119] are among the further 2D bimetallic alloys that have been created. In terms of OER performance, these structures were far more flexible than their bulk equivalents. Another study demonstrated that an electrocatalyst made of PdMo bimetallene-a palladium-molybdenum alloy organized in an extremely bowed, ultra-thin metal nanosheet-could stably reinforce the ORR and OER in electrolytes of basic nature [43,116,120–126]. For Li-air and Zn-air batteries, this bimetallene also works well as a cathode. The distinctive structural features of PdMo bimetallene, characterized by its thin-sheet structure, allow it to have a prominent atomic exploitation and a substantial electrochemically active surface area (140 m2 g−1 of Pd). At 1.0 volts in electrolytes of basic nature, the ORR demonstrates an MA of 17 amperes per milligram of Pd, which is lower than the reversible hydrogen electrode's MA of 16. The MA of this catalyst is 78 times greater than that of commercially available Pt/C catalysts and 327 times higher than that of Pd/C catalysts. The catalyst's performance remains consistent, still not satisfied after 30,000 cycles, which is rather remarkable. The enhanced performance of PdMo bimetallene is attributed to many variables according to density functional theory calculations. The nanosheet's thin structure causes several effects, including the strain due to the bent shape, the alloying upshot, and the impact of quantum dimensions. These parts work in tandem to fine-tune the electrical structure of the system, making it more efficient at binding oxygen. Complementary materials having a metallene framework like PdMo bimetallene may have significant promise for energy electrocatalysis, considering the evident properties and deep-rooted connections between framework and execution of PdMo bimetallene. A new class of 3D Cr-doped Pd metallene nanoribbons (PdCr MNRs) has been described in a separate study [127]. The three-dimensional PdCr MNR design had a thickness of around 3–6 atomic layers, had many flaws, and had Pd sites that were dense but poorly coordinated. The 3D PdCr MNR/C composite outperformed conventional Pt/C and Pd/C alternatives showed exceptional long-term durability, and significantly enhanced capabilities in the organic reduction process (ORR) and formic acid oxidation reaction (FAOR) when tested. The 1 T phase-IrO2 of iridium metallene oxide was described by Fan et al. [128]. Fig. 8 shows the OER execution of 1 T-IrO2. A combination of mechanochemistry and heat treatment in a strong alkaline environment is used to synthesize this chemical. Surprisingly, this material displays enhanced OER activity, as shown by its modest overpotential of 198 mV in the electrolyte of acidic nature at 10 mA cm−2. In addition, the 1 T-IrO2 has remarkable longevity, as shown by the fact that it degrades almost nothing even after being measured using chronopotentiometry for 126 h at a distinguished current density of 248 mA cm−2 in a proton interchange film gadget. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) in Fig. 8(a) shows that 1 T-IrO2 has the most active polarization curve, with a current density of 10 mA cm−2 accomplished at an ultralow overpotential of 197 mV. This overpotential is 100 mV lower than Rutile-IrO2, showing that the phase significantly affects the electrochemical performance. Overpotentials of 276 and 311 mV, respectively, were created by C-IrO2 and C-Ir/C, conversely (Fig. 8a). In contrast to Rutile-IrO2, C-IrO2, and C-Ir/C, 1 T-IrO2 had the best surface environment for the OER pathway, as shown by its minimal Tafel slope of 49 mV dec−1 (Fig. 8b). Fig. 8(c) shows that 1TeIrO2 has a geometrical current density of 52.7 mA cm−2, which is 9.6, 6.3, and 10.8 times more than Rutile-IrO2, C-IrO2, and C-Ir/C. As shown in Fig. 8(d), the mass activity of rutile-IrO2 is 10 folds lesser than that of 1 T-IrO2. Finding the TOF values for different catalysts (Fig. 8e and f) is very important. Following this, we have 1 T-IrO2, C-IrO2, Rutile-IrO2, and C-Ir/C as the TOF values. The maximum TOF value is achieved with 1 T-IrO2. Furthermore, the OER performance of 1 T-IrO2 was evaluated using an electrolyte of 0.5 M H2SO4. Using an elevated charge density of 50 mA cm−2, 1 T-IrO2 retained 98% of its initial activity during a 45-h stability test. Fig. 8(g) shows this. In contrast, the long-term test at the high current density rendered Rutile-IrO2, C-IrO2, and C-Ir/C entirely inactive. At a high current density of 50 mA cm−2, Fig. 8(i) displays the polarization curves based on UPD, whereas Fig. 8(h) displays the geometric polarization curves of 1 T-IrO2 both before and after the stability test. Although 1 T-IrO2′s active-area-based activity did reduce slightly, it was due mostly to the catalyst falling off the electrode during the stability test, which is why the OER activity was lost. 5.3 Alcohol and acid oxidation reaction In addition to OER, other important reactions in industry include formic acid oxidation reaction (FOR) and ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR), which are commonly found in direct liquid fuel cells and other energy conversion devices [129–132]. For these kinds of reactions, 2D metallenes with big specific areas should work well as catalysts. Take the freestanding hexagonal Pd nanosheets as an example. They demonstrated 2.5 times the electrocatalytic activity of commercial Pd, with a maximum current density of 1380 mA mg−1 (0.14 V versus SCE) [133]. When it comes to electrochemical oxygen reduction (EOR), Hong et al. [134] found that ultrathin Pd-Pt-Ag ternary alloy nanosheets, with a thickness of around 3 nm, achieved an outstanding activity of about 1.3 A mg−1. Furthermore, it was noted that Pt-Cu alloy nanosheets, which have a thickness ranging from 4 to 6 atomic layers, have an electrochemically active surface area of 62.8 m2 g−1 and exhibit superior electrocatalytic activity for electrooxidation reactions (EOR) when contrasted with Pt black and Pt/C [135]. 5.4 O2 reduction process Cathodic reactions in fuel cells and metal-air batteries rely heavily on the ORR. Its slow kinetics, however, are needed for effective ORR catalysts that can reduce overpotentials and boost efficiency. A catalyst's efficacy can be predicted or designed using the Sabatier principle. This concept states that the binding energies of reactants or intermediates to catalysts should be just right, neither too strong nor too weak [136]. So, the electronic structure of the catalysts and the projected binding energy from Density Functional Theory may be used as a quantitative indicator to identify potential electrocatalysts. When considering the kinetics of an electrocatalytic process, it is crucial to account for the effects of interfacial solvation and electric fields. As a result, developing catalysts necessitates thinking about various techniques to control their electrical structures. Common components of such strategies include alterations to ligands, transfers of charges, changes in geometry, lattice tensions, and combinations of these factors. The distinct structural benefit of metallenes in the context of the ORR becomes obvious with closer inspection of specific instances. In comparison to a commercial benchmark Pt/C catalyst, Pd metallenes demonstrated superior ORR activity and catalytic stability [38]. This exemplifies the distinctive ways in which metallenes may improve catalytic performance, making them stand out. Electrocatalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) that are effective have been produced from platinum-group metals and related alloys due to their appropriate oxygen-binding energies. The catalyst surface and O2 have an appropriate binding energy, and these materials are active and durable in acidic conditions [137]. The ORR relies too heavily on costly Pt-based catalysts because of its slow cathode reaction kinetics, which are caused by the difficult activation and fragmentation of O=O bonds [138]. This pending action makes it harder to mass-produce fuel cells for commercial use. Making 2D noble metal nanosheets is a good way to get around this problem. These nanosheets have many unsaturated atoms, kinks, and edges, which make them ideal for O2 adsorption and activation. As a result, the ORR's kinetics are improved by this setup. For example, by topotactic reducing platinum oxide nanosheets to the topotactic, Sugimoto and colleagues were able to successfully fabricate Pt nanolayers with a width of 0.4 nm [139]. Using electrochemical erosion of 2D PtTe2 nanosheets, Huang and colleagues synthesized porous Pt metallenes [140]. When compared to a commercial Pt/C catalyst, these Pt metallenes demonstrated a 9.8-fold increase in mass and a 10.7-fold increase in specific activity in the ORR. The introduction of nanopores, boundaries, and vacancies caused by electrocatalytic corrosion was thought to be responsible for this astounding improvement. Because of these factors, there were less coordinated Pt points, which are centers for electron depletion that decide a successful ORR. Despite 30,000 cycles, the distorted Pt metallene exhibited no signs of activity reduction or structural alterations. The fact that Pt-based catalysts' activity degrades, leading to CO poisoning during ORRs, is a big roadblock to their commercialization. As a result, compared to Pt/C in the ORR, FePt nanosheets with distributed Pt atoms demonstrated seven times higher MA and improved CO tolerance [141]. Enhanced functioning is attributed to improved electronic conduction, quicker charge transmission, and an extremely effective usage of Pt atoms spread throughout a 2D folded structural configuration. The reason PtFe has such a high resistance to CO is because of its lower adsorption energy, which is yielded likely by the amount of OH groups formed close to Fe widgets. This design is useful for preventing Pt from absorbing CO. The addition of carbon doping to metallenes increases their catalytic activity and durability with respect to the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), according to research by Zhang et al. [142]. Fig. 9 shows the process of considering PdMo bimetallene. Then, carbon-doped and undoped Pd95Mo5 bimetallenes were incorporated onto carbon black and tested as electrocatalysts for alkaline organic redox reactions. A Pt/C catalyst that is currently on the market was used as a benchmark for this evaluation. The different peaks associated with Pd were seen in the cyclic voltammograms (CVs) of Pd95Mo5 bimetallene/C and carbon doped Pd95Mo5 bimetallene/C. In oxygen reduction reactions (ORRs), carbon doped PdMo bimetallene shows nearly double the mass and specific activity of its undoped cousin. In addition, after thirty thousand cycles, the carbon-doped version of the bimetallene maintains around 3 folds higher molybdenum (Mo) than the non-doped equivalent. Covalent bonds produced by hybridization of Mo and C orbitals are revealed to be formed during carbon inclusion using X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) and computational models. In addition to stabilizing Mo species and protecting them from oxidation, this bonding improves oxygen binding. As a result, the catalyst's stability and performance are significantly improved in several ways. 5.5 Fuel oxidation process One of the anodic half-reactions that happens in fuel cells is the Fuel Oxidation Reaction (FOR). Potential energy carriers that can produce electricity when mixed with electrocatalysts include chemical energy sources like ethylene glycol, methyl alcohol, and methanal. This highlights the need to create FOR catalysts with high efficiency, which is critical for fuel cell industrialization. Although many other materials have been developed as electrocatalysts for FORs, catalysts based on noble metals are still very important because of their remarkable activity [143]. 2D nanosheets made of palladium (Pd) and platinum (Pt) have been investigated extensively as electrocatalysts for ferroelectrics (FORs). These materials' many advantages include rapid mass and electron transfer, numerous exterior positions, and a large explicit surface area. Due to these properties, 2D nanosheets based on Pt and Pd have become the focus of research on efficient electrocatalysis for FORs. The research group led by Huang successfully manufactured extremely thin triangular Pt nanosheets. These nanosheets are composed of mono- layers of extremely tiny nanocrystals, each measuring around 4.0 nm in size. In the perspective of the methanol oxidation process (MOR), these nanosheets proved to be more effective than commercial Pt/C catalysts, which is rather remarkable [144]. Recent work has shown that 2D Pd59Fe27Pt14 nano meshes engineered via spin engineering may produce an electrocatalyst with remarkable solidity and action in the MOR [145]. A strong correlation between MOR activity and Pd x Fe y Pt z 's spin state was noted by the authors. In particular, the magnetic moment linked to each Fe atom in Pd x Fe y Pt z followed a pattern that looked like a volcano as the amount of Fe doping rose. The most important finding was that this trend was consistent with a similar pattern observed in MOR activity. Lately, a lot of people are interested in using 2D metallenes as electrocatalysts to oxidize C2 fuels like ethylene glycol and ethanol [146]. Their many benefits—including safe storage, high boiling temperatures, low toxicity, and energy density—are the driving forces behind this interest. As an example, for the EOR, a set of bimetallic PdM nanosheets (where M = Zn, Cd, or ZnCd) with a width of lower than 5 nm has been created [105]. The performance of the produced PdZn metallene is interesting since it shows greatly improved electrochemical capabilities. The PdZn metallene showed a 1.74-fold and a 2.97-fold improvement in MA for the EOR in a 1.0 M NaOH + 1.0 M methanol solution, contrasting to pristine Pd nanolayers and industrial Pd black, respectively. The amazing performance of 2D PdZn metallene was credited to the combined effects of ligands and quantum size, which resulted from the alloying operations and the ultrathin structure, respectively. Another example is the creation of Pd-PdSe heterostructure nanosheets that exhibit a tensile strain effect and p-d hybridization [147]. This structure showed outstanding performance in the ethylene glycol oxidation process and very high discrimination in the C1 path in a solution of 1.0 M KOH and 1.0 M ethylene glycol. Particularly, compared to Pd nanosheets and a commercial Pd/C catalyst, the specific activity of Pd-PdSe nanosheets was 2.5 times higher and 5.5 times higher, respectively. A two-dimensional fine platinum-tellurium alloy metallene, PtTe A-ML, is made utilizing a conventional liquid-phase chemical reduction process for application in direct formic acid fuel cells (DFAFCs) [148]. The exceptional electrocatalytic performance of PtTe A-ML in the FAOR is due in part to its alloying effect and its unique properties of high atomic utilization. Fig. 10 shows the direct oxidation process of FAOR, which can be fully realized using PtTe A-ML. By doing so, we have improved the FAOR process's kinetics and significantly reduced the production of harmful carbon monoxide intermediates. When it comes to acidic conditions, PtTe A-ML has an FAOR activity that is 45 times higher than commercial Pt nanocrystals and 5.6 times higher than Pd nanocrystals. Furthermore, the electrocatalytic capacity of PtTe A-ML in the CO oxidation process is quite amazing. This property is due to the electron transfer that occurs between Pt and Te once oxygenophilic Te atoms are added. Because of this interaction, PtTe A-ML is more efficient at oxidizing CO and lasts longer when exposed to FAOR. 5.6 Nitrogen reduction reaction (N2RR) A potential and cost-effective method for making ammonia in mild environments without using fossil fuels or emitting CO2 is electrochemical N2 reduction. Thus, creating electrocatalysts for the N2RR that are both stable and efficient is eagerly sought after [105,141–152]. New evidence suggests that 2D metals, which have larger specific surfaces and shorter carrier diffusion paths, are stable and very active electrocatalysts for the N2RR. For instance, an inorganic polymer cyanogel reduction technique was used to manufacture surfactant-free Rh nanosheet nano assemblies with atomically thin structures. These nano assemblies were then utilized as effective electrocatalysts for the N2RR [153]. Despite having a low FE of 0.217% at a potential of −0.2 V in an alkaline electrolyte, the Rh nanosheets demonstrated a high rate of NH3 generation (23.88 μg h−1 mg−1 cat.) because of their optimized electronic structure, numerous coordination unsaturated atoms, and high specific surface area. Fig. 11 (a) shows the results of the N2RR, which was successfully catalyzed by 2D PdFe1 single-atom alloy nanosheets that were also synthesized [154]. At a potential of −0.2 V, the PdFe1 electrocatalyst demonstrated exceptional N2RR activities, yielding 111.9 μg h−1 mg−1 of NH3 and a FE of 37.8%. In comparison to Pd nanosheets, these values are 7.1% and 9.7% higher, respectively (Fig. 11b and c). Extensive research showed that the separated Fe atoms in PdFe1 had their electronic configuration changed, which improved their capacity to chemisorb N2 (Fig. 11d) and allowed for the activation, dissociation, intermediate stabilization, and continuous protonation of N2. The improved yield, selectivity, and stability with respect to N2RR were all brought about by these considerations. There are two main benefits of using bimetals as an electrocatalyst for the N2RR instead of noble metals. The first step is that the unfilled antibonding orbitals of N2 may be filled up by using the electrons donated by the occupied p-orbitals of Bi metals. The N2RR activity has improved because this increases N2 adsorption and activation. Furthermore, the competitive HER process is efficiently suppressed by Bi materials because of their poor binding energy with H atoms, which results in lower HER electrocatalytic efficacy. As an example, 2D Bi nanosheets exhibiting a defect-rich structure were created by a low-temperature plasma bombardment method. These nanosheets then proved to be effective electrocatalysts for N2RR, without the need for noble metals. Under ambient circumstances in a Na2SO4 solution, the 2D Bi structure with defects showed a high FE of 11.68% at a potential of −0.6 V compared to RHE, and a 15NH3 production rate of 5.453 μg mgBi −1 h−1 at a potential of −0.9 V compared to RHE [155]. The profusion of flaws in the 2D Bi nanosheets presumably generated the better activity of the 2D Bi, which is favorable for the electrochemical reduction of N2 to NH3. These defects also aid in N2 adsorption and activation. Compared to Bi nanoparticles, the electrochemically reduced bismuth nanosheets showed better electrocatalytic activity for N2RR [156]. These nanosheets are generated from layered bismuth oxyhalides. Electron delocalization in bismuth's p-orbital and the increased density of edge atoms were found to be responsible for the improved activity. Using hydrated potassium cations, Cheng, and colleagues [157] found that a few-layer antimonene was an effective N2RR electrocatalyst. Hydrated K+ ions can stabilize *NNH intermediates and decrease HER, according to this study. Hydrogen bonding, electrostatic interactions between K+ ions and N atoms, and a rise in the energy barrier for proton migration are the interactions that create this result [45]. 5.7 CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) process Unchecked combustion of fossil fuels has increased CO2 emissions, which in turn has worsened environmental degradation and created a major threat in the shape of climate change [158]. To achieve a carbon-neutral energy cycle, cutting-edge CO2 fixation technologies must be developed. Nevertheless, accomplishing this objective is challenging since carbon dioxide (CO2) is a thermodynamically stable molecule with the greatest oxidation state of carbon [159]. The electrochemical CO2RR has newly trapped a considerable curiosity as a potential solution to the problem of CO2 fixation by transforming CO2 into useful carbonaceous chemicals. Formate (HCOOH/HCOO−) is an interesting and potentially useful substance, especially for fuel cells that use formic acid (HCOOH) and hydrogen carriers [160]. The qualities of formate that make it appealing are its increased safety and ease of storage. Less than an ideal catalytic efficiency, severe overpotential, and low energy transformation competence are obstacles to the broad use of large-scale CO2RR systems, notwithstanding their potential [161]. Given these obstacles, the development of electrocatalysts that are both highly efficient and systematically designed is of the utmost importance. The need to address the aforesaid difficulties and progress in the actual use of CO2RR technology is driving this need. Electrocatalysts based on metals including zinc, copper, silver, and palladium are extensively employed for CO2RR. These metals are useful as electrocatalysts for the CO2RR because they fall into one of three categories based on the binding affinities of their intermediates and major products. (1) Au, Ag, Zn, and Pd are primarily used to create CO. (2) Formate is made using Sn, Bi, Pb, and In. (3) Copper may make multi-carbon compounds. Difficulties arise due to the CO2RR's HERs being byproducts, the catalysts' high kinetic barriers, and the multielectron transfer mechanism's complexity. Optimal yield rates and selectivity are not achieved when these factors are combined [12]. 2D metallic nanosheets are more electrocatalytically efficient for reducing CO2RR because they have a higher concentration of unsaturated surface atoms compared to bulk metals. A relatively innovation is the fabrication of asymmetrically puckered Pd nanolayers featuring uncovered (100) facets. This was achieved by transforming fine Pd nanosheets that were characterized by a high concentration of defects and mostly composed of (111) facets [162]. Because of this alteration, the surface had to be rebuilt, which increased the number of active sites while simultaneously decreased the intensity of CO adsorption. By restoring the surface, we were able to facilitate CO2 conversion, which led to a 93% FE for CO production on the restored Pd nanosheets at 0.7 V vs RHE. Also, the CO2RR catalysts, triangular Ag nanoplates, had a higher CO FE of 96.8% than the 65.4% FE Ag nanoparticles [163]. The improved catalytic performance in the CO2RR is due to the higher presence of edge sites on Ag nanoplates. Adsorption of CO2 and production of intermediate COOH were both enhanced by these periphery sites, which in turn increased the process's overall efficiency. For the CO2RR in acetonitrile, Rosenthal et al. studied Bi-based compounds and surface-modified Bi nanoparticles, with an ionic liquid (IL) acting as the auxiliary electrolyte. The most important byproduct in this setting was CO [70,164,165]. Electrodeposited Bi showed a significant increase in CO generation in circumstances with a modest potential. Imidazolium cations enabled the strong stabilization of CO2 intermediates, which led to this efficiency. It is worth mentioning that CO, being an essential part of syngas, is used as a feedstock to produce olefins using Fischer-Tropsch technology [166]. Nevertheless, controlling the IL's breakdown at high voltages was a difficult task. The reduced stability and greater cost of bi-based catalysts in organic media compared to aqueous systems limited their application potential in the CO2RR. Using a liquid-exfoliation process, ultrathin 2D bismuth (Bi) nanosheets may be produced, which can enhance the electrocatalytic conversion of CO2 [167]. When it comes to CO2 adsorption and reaction kinetics, ultrathin Bi nanosheets appear to be crucial due to the increased presence of edge sites compared to bulk Bi. This improvement greatly facilitates the transformation of carbon dioxide into format (HCOOH/HCOO−). This pattern, supported by reduced Gibbs free energies, was confirmed by density-functional theory (DFT) calculations, which showed that *OCOH production often takes place on edge sites rather than facet sites. Using the nanosheets' abundant surface areas and excellent conductivity, we were able to produce format with an outstanding FE of 86.0% and a current density of 16.5 mA cm−2 at 1.1 V (compared to RHE). The results are much better than what you would get with bulk Bi. The Bi nanosheets' catalytic activity was also well-preserved throughout continuous 10-h long-term testing. Simplified one-pot solvothermal synthesis was used by Zhang et al. to produce 2D curved porous Pd metallene nanoparticles doped with copper [168]. The improved catalysts that came out of it were shown to be strong bifunctional electrocatalysts that could do cathodal ORR and anodic FAO all at once. The discovered PdCu metallene stood out with outstanding properties such a high MA of 1.227 A mgPt −1 in basic nature solutions and an outstanding half-wave potential of 0.943 V vs. RHE. By a factor of 1.09 and 6.26, respectively, these values outstrip the commercial Pt/C alternative. In an electrolyte containing 0.5 M H2SO4 and 0.5 M HCOOH, measurements were done at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1, as shown in Fig. 12 (a). The picture shows that compared to JM 20% Pd/C, PdCu has a greater peak current density. PdCu metallene has a higher kinetic efficiency and a stronger ability towards FAO, as shown in Fig. 12(b), which shows that its onset potential (E onset) is negatively shifted compared to Pd/C. Fig. 12(c) shows that the MA of PdCu is 905.5 A mgPd −1, which is significantly broader than that of commercial Pd/C, which is 328.1 A mgPd −1. Fig. 12(d) shows the results of the stability analysis using chromatoamperometry. We tested the FAO stability of PdCu metallene in a solution of 0.5 M H2SO4 and 0.5 M HCOOH at 0.2 V for 3600 s to see how it held up over time. To begin, the increased current density is due to the larger concentration of HCOOH molecules.
